title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
US president Joe Biden is set to tighten “buy American” provisions as part of a push to boost domestic manufacturing, in a move that risks straining relations with key US allies.

Mr Biden is on Monday expected to order an increase in domestic content requirements for the $600bn federal procurement industry, following a campaign pledge to boost US manufacturing as he aimed to outflank Donald Trump in key swing states.

Meanwhile, the Biden administration has taken its first steps towards reviving the flagging US economy. The US president on Friday signed two executive orders to broaden access to food stamps and unemployment benefits, while beginning a process to introduce a mandatory $15 per hour minimum wage for federal contractors.

The new administration warned, however, that the executive orders were “not a substitute” for its $1.9tn stimulus package. The president is facing a narrow window to secure bipartisan support for his new relief package after congressional Democrats said they wanted a deal before Donald Trump's second impeachment trial begins the week of February 8.

Sign-up to Swamp Notes for reaction to the latest developments in Washington from columnists Rana Foroohar and Edward Luce. (FT)

Coronavirus digest

  • Walmart, Amazon and even a Las Vegas casino are offering to help give Covid-19 shots, as the Biden administration aims to accelerate the US vaccine rollout.

  • Mexico's president Andrés Manuel López Obrador, who has refused to wear a face mask, has tested positive.

  • Brazil's week-old inoculation campaign is already facing bottlenecks because of vital pharmaceutical supplies stuck overseas.

  • The Dutch prime minister promised to crack down on anti-lockdown protests that swept through the country and turned violent over the weekend.

  • Sweden will close its border with Norway after the latter introduced its strictest measures of the pandemic so far because of cases of the UK variant.

  • The EU's vaccine procurement strategy is under scrutiny as member states have struggled to roll out rapid vaccinations. (FT)

After a month in hospital, FT restaurant critic Tim Hayward reflects on his battle with coronavirus. Follow our live blog for the latest Covid-19 news.

In the news

White nationalists target scattered Trump supporters Extreme rightwing supporters are seizing the opportunity to further radicalise the fragmented pro-Donald Trump movement, after crackdowns by large social networks scattered the former US president's most ardent supporters on to fringe platforms. (FT)

Shale producers fear drilling binge will spoil good times With the US oil benchmark now trading at $53 a barrel most shale operators can turn a profit but resisting the urge to start producing more crude may prove difficult, say executives, who worry about protecting margins. (FT)

Top hedge funds reap biggest gains in a decade The 20 best-performing hedge fund managers of all time made $63.5bn for investors during the coronavirus-driven market turmoil in 2020, making it the industry's best year of gains in a decade. (FT)

BaFin boss ‘believed' Wirecard was victim The head of Germany's financial watchdog suggested Wirecard might be the victim of an elaborate short sellers' plot even after the company discovered that €1.9bn of its stated cash was missing, according to three people briefed on the matter and a document seen by the Financial Times.

  • Vienna police have arrested a former senior official of the Austrian secret service and a former rightwing MP over the escape of Wirecard's former second-in-command Jan Marsalek last summer. (FT)

Deutsche probes alleged mis-selling Deutsche Bank is investigating whether its staff mis-sold sophisticated investment banking products to clients in breach of EU rules and then colluded with individuals within these companies to share the profits. (FT)

Russia's Navalny protests More than 2,000 supporters of Putin critic Alexei Navalny have been detained after attending peaceful protests across Russia over the weekend. The protests were reminiscent of the scenes that have wracked Belarus for the past five months. Andrzej Duda, Poland's president, has urged the EU to step up sanctions against Russia. (FT)

Kuaishou prices Hong Kong IPO TikTok rival Kuaishou is set to raise up to $6.3bn in a Hong Kong initial public offering in a test of investor appetite for China's tech sector as it faces growing regulatory scrutiny. The deal would be the largest tech IPO since Uber went to market in 2019. (FT)

The day ahead

Trump impeachment Nancy Pelosi, Speaker of the US House of Representatives, is expected to send the article impeaching former president Donald Trump to the Senate on Monday. The upper chamber is also set to vote on Janet Yellen's nomination as Treasury secretary. (FT, Reuters)

Virtual Davos World leaders including China's president Xi Jinping, India's prime minister Narendra Modi, German chancellor Angela Merkel and South Africa's president Cyril Ramaphosa, among others, are expected to participate in this week's online event. The Davos ski resort, meanwhile, is eerily quiet. (AP, Reuters)

WHO report The World Health Organization will publish a report warning that advanced economies will face a significant economic hit unless they help developing countries speed up vaccination programmes. (FT)

Greece-Turkey talks Greece and Turkey are set to resume talks in Istanbul aimed at resolving differences over maritime borders and energy exploitation after a four-year pause. (Reuters)

What else we're reading

Joe Biden and the ‘great rebalancing' of the US economy In many ways this is a difficult moment for the Biden administration to turn the tide on worker pay. But there are three big reasons why we may still be at a key inflection point in the US labour-capital divide, writes Rana Foroohar. (FT)

Can Trump staffers find lobbying jobs? On entering office Donald Trump demanded that any incoming member of his administration sign a pledge that they would not engage in lobbying for at least five years after leaving public service. But on Wednesday at 1am, the outgoing president revoked Executive Order 13770, in one of his final acts before departing the White House. (FT)

Stock market ‘bubble' anxiety Screaming stock rallies and wild speculation by have-a-go amateur investors are stirring concerns among market veterans of a bubble to rival anything seen in the past century. This article is the first in the FT's Runaway Markets series. (FT)

Sony's new weapon to battle Netflix A newly invigorated Sony is competing with Netflix and global streaming companies to uncover the still untapped trove of lucrative anime, whose profit potential in a digital world is transforming how media companies look at the genre. (FT)

Abu Dhabi's point man The rise of the UAE's national security adviser over the past decade epitomises the nexus between power, business and national strategic interest in Gulf states, where a younger, tech-savvy and security-minded generation of royals has come to the fore. Meet Sheikh Tahnoon bin Zayed al-Nahyan. (FT)

Why you should ditch ‘follow your passion' careers advice In her new book Work Won't Love You Back, Sarah Jaffe writes that “labour of love . . . is a con”. The book shows how the myth permeates diverse jobs and sectors and serves as a timely reminder of the importance of re-evaluating your relationship to work, writes Emma Jacobs. (FT)

Podcast of the day

Germany after Merkel Germany's ruling Christian Democratic Union has chosen Armin Laschet to replace Angela Merkel as its leader. Gideon Rachman discusses what a post-Merkel Germany will look like with Wolfgang Ischinger, veteran diplomat and chairman of the Munich Security Conference. Listen on FT.com, Spotify, or Apple podcasts.
